title: For those stuck in silver or bronze
body:
If you are stuck in silver or bronze, but would like to be a higher rank I just wanted to remind you their is hope. I have leveled two accounts to gold this season playing mostly solo and multiple roles. The only thing limiting yourself from ranking up is you. There are many guides and strategies out there on how to rank up written by players much more knowledgeable than myself. The only advice I have is knowledge is power. The more your learn about this game and the more you play the better you become. This is obvious but many of us casual players take this obvious advice for granted. So when high elo players provide us advice and give us tips its good to listen. 

Anyways, happy grinding. Don't tilt. Don't give up.

Truer words have never been spoken. This whole mentality where "it's not the team's fault, it's yours" is backwards ass thinking and retarded to boot, with its popularity only being so high due to the fact that it makes players look more "humble and responsible". If you win your lane, ward the map, and roam to help out, and your team does the opposite, then it is legitimately not your fault, because that shows you did your job and displayed competence as a player.

Actually you're wrong. It is possible for a single person to solo carry out of Bronze. I myself have had some success carrying myself out of B5 all the way to B2 promos by cleaning up some aspects of my own play. I learned to cs, better, focused more on pushing than trying to pad my KDA, learned to trade better in lane and it really helped. 

Don't get me wrong. There are a many games that are simply uncarriable for the slightly above average Bronze player and even then those games are carriable too, just not by us.

Look at this guy:-
http://na.op.gg/summoner/userName=dragonsoysauce

A couple weeks ago he played Sivir on the enemy team and he just straight up fuckin wrecked us. I swear this dude carried the entire game by himself. He played so goddamn good that even if two of his team mates went AFK we would have still lost. That's how fuckin good he was. His team barely even mattered. I felt like me and my team were beginner AIs just waiting to feed this guy. We just could not stop his relentless assault.

The problem though, is that most of us will never be that good. But, I've seen that it certainly is possible to be so good that no bullshit your team does can jeopardize your victory.

I agree with you, this low elo "my team causes me to lose" attitude is just so bad. I was also bronze once, as were most of us that are now in gold and plat. And we got out. Might've taken us a while to do it, but we did. And let me be the first to say, the "I don't make mistakes, but my team still loses the game" attitude is the number 1 reason why you are stuck. You literally CANNOT improve your play if you think like this. Start taking charge of the game, be a leader, ward the map, stop bitching and play the game. When you lose, try to think of what YOU personally could have done to prevent it. If you can think of nothing, then enjoy your steady decline to bronze 5. And I'm not saying that your team won't occasionally fuck you over, but the same will happen on the enemy team with IDENTICAL FREQUENCY. Unless, of course, YOU are the one that's fucking your team over...

Everything you say is true but to play devil's advocate, learning to overcome Bronze is really fuckin hard. I think this is why so many people complain. Just a while back today I decided I'm giving up on trying. I'm just gonna play for playing sake and do whatever the hell. It's just way too stressful. I really put a lot of effort into it and despite how many people say its easy to get out, my best effort only got me to B2 promos and that's after hitting B4 and dropping back down to B5 0 LP no less than 10 times this season.

I know its my own fault that I can't get out but I think I got caught up in all the "oh Bronze so easy, just do this and that and you'll get out easy". I've only just realized that in reality it takes a tonne of practice and research, watching videos and streams, just a fuck tonne of effort and frankly, I'm exhausted. I have a life and I really cannot devote all this effort to become that good at a video game. I've made up my mind that when I inevitably fall back to B5 0 LP, I'm done with ranked. I'm just gonna play casual and just have fun. 

I think a lot of people complaining about how hard it is to climb should do the same. The effort you have to put in is far more that people realize and unless you're prepared to devote 8 hrs a day playing this, you shouldn't be aiming to climb.

I never said it was easy to get out of bronze, and honestly whenever someone tells me that this game is easy, I seriously want to punch them in the mouth. It's a hard game, especially when you are new at it (which a lot of bronze/silver players are). But this doesn't mean that it's not a manageable feat. And as soon as you drop the "fuck me team" attitude, you will see immediate results. I know from experience, because used to be like this. Then I started focusing on improving my own play, and after a shitload of games, hit plat last season. So it's 100% doable if you have the right attitude.

No no. I'm not saying it's not doable. What I'm saying is that the effort required is enormous. When high elo people are always ragging on about how Bronze is easy and how bad Bronze is, it gives the impression that's it's relatively easy to get out. Based on my own rate of improvement, I'd say even getting to Silver is an amazing feat of determination. While yes, Silver is low elo, anyone who makes it there has my respect. It takes real effort and not 2 hours on a weekend kind of effort. I can only imagine what it takes to get to Diamond. You'd have to live, sleep and shit this game to get that good.

Thing is most people think they can just spam a couple games now and again, watch a couple streams and that's enough. Not even close.

Getting out of bronze is probably 10% teamwork skill, 5% mechanical skill, and 85% attitude. This is really not even that much of an exaggeration. If you can keep a positive outlook on your own play and your own improvement, it really isn't that hard. When pro players and other high elo players get their smurfs out of bronze 5 in an afternoon, they aren't showcasing the attitude portion at all because they don't need to. They are so mechanically skilled, that the other 2 portions don't really matter. Keep a positive attitude, identify and learn from your mistakes (which means you MUST be open to criticism), and be willing to swallow your pride every now and then for good of the team (which is really for your own good also) and you will get out of bronze a lot faster than you think.

I have that passion that a lot of people have lost.

I've hit B4 something like 7 times this season and got beat right back down to B5 0 LP. Recently, I finally managed to make it to B2 promos which I lost and I'm currently falling right back down again. No doubt I'll once again be B5 0 LP by the next couple days. It is next to impossible to keep a positive attitude. This shit if seriously discouraging. Losing 7 games in a row makes me wonder if I learned anything at all or if almost reaching B2 is luck. I'm really starting to think there is a great luck factor involved, at least for me.

"No doubt I'll once again be B5 0 LP" that statement and thought it was you want to try to avoid. Losing streaks do suck and everyone has them. Losing streaks create tilt, which then worsens one's play and leads to more losses. I am speaking from experience. 

Do you feel you have gotten better as a player? Do you feel more confident in your decisions? Have you been putting up better scores? Are you hard carrying games or are your games pretty difficult for you? These are all sorts of questions to look at to try and analyze if you are getting better. When you lose two or more  games in a row I suggest taking a break. He can be a relatively short break, but something to distract you so you can stop thinking about that last game and can free your mind and hopefully play better in the next game.

My losing streak started like 3 days ago. I doubt this tilt is lasting several days. To be honest, I really don't know why this happens. I'm thinking luck has some factor to play in this. Every time I climb, I do it on win streaks, most of which I'm carrying. When I start falling, it's usually due to a high amount of uncarriable games. My 1st few loses after losing B2 promos, had me getting teams that feed close to 15 kills in the space of 10 minutes. I have no idea how to carry these games, even if I play snowball champs. After that I start playing like shit, feeding and all that, the tilt you were talking about. I took a break, came back and 1st game after my break, another uncarriable game, followed by another. Pretty much gave up trying hard after that and just let the fall happen. I actually think it's better that I accept that I'll fall right back down because when I expect anything else and get disappointed, it gets me in a bad mood. 

Eventually, I'll climb back up. I can get B4 pretty consistently now. B3 takes more effort and a little luck. Still working on B2.

damn man I want to help you haha. Looks like your three main champs currently are {{champion:268}} {{champion:39}} {{champion:10}} all of whom I don't really play. Azir has a pretty high  skill cap and is op at like mid/low Diamond + but not until that skill cap. Kayle can carry if you know how to play her right. {{champion:39}}  can carry as well. 

Your csing looks to be pretty good in most games which is encouraging. However, it looks like you die a decent amount. So let me ask you. Do you just sit in lane and farm and push most of the game or do you roam at all? Ultimately csing and pushing lane are generally more important, but ganking lanes when your mid can help the team out a lot. Especially if you are running teleport. Also, with your average of 10-11 deaths a game in recent games it looks like you might be getting killed by ganks a lot? Or dying right away in team fights? You should work on your positioning so you can do damage in team fights, yet also stay alive. And make sure you have wards or try and keep track of where the enemy is so you don't get ganked and die as often. 

What I do when I am playing in bronze and trying to rank up is play a champ I am confident I can carry In. I then try my hardest to not only cs in lane, but win the lane by killing my opponent over & over. If the enemy is not a hard counter to me (even if they are a lot of the time) I am generally able to get some kills in lane while continuing to cs. I then look for opportunities to gank lanes to 1. help my allies, but 2. more importantly try and get myself more kills. Even though you can only rely on yourself to rank up, bronze is the lowest elo and the least likely elo where you can rely on your allies to help carry. You no doubt are going to probably have to carry some games 1v5. So its all about getting yourself or whoever is fed on your team as fed as possible. The good news is, besides smurfs most people in bronze are there for a reason. So its the easiest elo to get super fed and hard carry in. The more you learn the easier it is to carry in other elos as well. 

I know its hard to see the light without experiencing it, but its there. Its embarrassing how much I have played this game and seeing how bad I am. I had probably 400-500 normal wins before even playing ranked in season 2. My elo in season 2 was probably the equivalent of bronze 4. Then when season 3 came around and the system changed I was put in bronze 4. I was pissed, but knew I had to work to rank up. Not sure why but I decided to play adc. I mained {{champion:110}} adc in season 3, which pretty much got me out of bronze. I laugh really hard about it now because I never play him anymore and I look back at my season 3 stats and see how terrible they are. Then in season 4 I got up to silver 2 and could not figure out why I could not get past it. Took literally over a year of grinding silver until roughly the end of season 5 before I realized silver 2 was my actual current elo. I finally realized I just needed to improve to start to rank up. It really did not take long to improve enough to reach gold after realizing that. Now I realize I will stick around gold 4-5 unless I continue to improve. 

The good news is there is lots of things to improve on. Start with the basics and work your way up. Focus on winning your lane hard, but play safe if you fall behind. Focus on trying to catch enemies with ganks and try to snowball the game. Work on your team fight positioning. Warding and paying attention to your mini map is also important.

Just wanted to update. Think I just had a breakthrough. I stumbled upon a video yesterday. I think it was called freezing to Diamond or something like that. He talk about freezing lane. Now, I've watched a lot of these kinds of videos so I know what freezing is, hell I've done it. But I didn't really get it. I knew what it was and how to do it sure but I never really grasped its power. I just thought it was some cutesy thing you can do to frustrate your opponent or make a hard lane easier. This specific video mentioned how it can be used to get fed. I didn't really make the connection.

Just played a game and decided for the hell of it, I'll just freeze the fuck out of the lane. I was Azir going up against a Syndra. The result ? I shit on that Syndra. Killed her something like 3 times within the space of 5 minutes. Because of the freeze, she had to come close my tower to cs and I'd just shuffle her into my tower, and ignite or auto attack her to death. Worked so beautifully. 

Now I'm probably gonna try it again and I may very well get wrecked this time. I've had similar breakthroughs before that seemed to work for a while and then it stops working. I don't expect I'll start steamrolling now, but I know something I didn't yesterday. And with some practice, I have yet another thing I can abuse to win in Bronze.

Just wanted to let you know since you touched on this in our discussion.

Yea it really is great. Since that 1st game, I used it for every game afterwards, went on a 7 game win streak. Got from B4 0LP to B3 with almost no losses. I did it using Kayle top exclusively. 80% of players in Bronze really don't know what do when they are freezed out. I was able to zone them from csing and later, outright kill them or force a back every time they attempt to cs. 

The only problem I have to solve now is freezing opponents who can out trade me. I had problems with Nasus and Olaf due to the fact that they can build MR items first while doing insane damage early game. When I freezed on them and poked them when they tried to farm, they would trade and win almost every time.
Nice there you go! Yea freezing a very good strategy. Keep up the learning and practicing and you will be out of bronze in no time.

I settled on those 3 because frankly I just get them. I have an affinity for sustain damage champs which I why I play Kayle and Azir alot. I like Irelia because she can build super tanky and still deal massive amounts of burst. Plus she's like sleeper OP, ie, nobody bans her and she's not a contested pick. However, it's a coin toss with Irelia. With Azir and Kayle, there are hardly any lanes that present a problem. They can cs insanely well and I love love love their waveclear.

 > Your csing looks to be pretty good in most games which is encouraging. However, it looks like you die a decent amount. So let me ask you. Do you just sit in lane and farm and push most of the game or do you roam at all? Ultimately csing and pushing lane are generally more important, but ganking lanes when your mid can help the team out a lot. Especially if you are running teleport. 

Roaming is a tricky thing. If I'm against a strong pusher like Yasuo, roaming is out of the question. He shoves too fast so I'm pretty much always pinned against my tower. Using roams in more favorable matchups, mostly to prevent feeds at bot lane which happens in 95% of Bronze games, I discovered that it is detrimental if your roams yield nothing. Meaning, you MUST get a tower, a kill, something otherwise you fall behind. Last few games I just stopped roaming all together because its too unreliable. I try to stay in lane as push as hard as I can to get towers as fast as I can. Kayle top is incredibly good at this. Sometimes, I would do this until I'm near full build. It actually worked for a while. Got me to B2 promos then it stopped working. 


> Also, with your average of 10-11 deaths a game in recent games it looks like you might be getting killed by ganks a lot? 

Actually, last 10 games or so I was really fuckin tilted. I was just playing very carelessly. Its easy for me if I want not to die at all. There was a recent game somewhere in my match list where my team fed super super super hard and I was 2-0. So I know how not to die. Most of my deaths come from jumping into fights my team starts that I know we'd probably lose but still do in the mad hope that I can turn it around. Sometimes I can, sometimes I cannot. I really don't know what to do sometimes when my team goes in for a fight that is unfavorable. 95% of my deaths come from this.

Here's an example. Say I'm top on the red side and I see my jungler following the low HP mid laner after a skirmish. And he is running from mid to top. Now I'm fighting with the enemy top laner and my jungler is pinging for help. This is a bad fight because to start because 90% of the time we do not know where the enemy jungler is. But what can I do ? Leave him to die ? I will intercept the fleeing enemy. Their top would follow me, and when the fight starts, the enemy jungler would come out of now where and now it's 3v2. The vast majority of my deaths come from situations like this. In my view, no one should ever chase someone into unwarded territory yet I keep getting dragged into fights with no vision trying to cover my team mate's stupid decisions and often end up paying for it with my life. In this example, the correct thing would be for my jungler to break off pursuit. Thirst is the number 1 reason for feed fests in Bronze.  

>Or dying right away in team fights? You should work on your positioning so you can do damage in team fights, yet also stay alive. And make sure you have wards or try and keep track of where the enemy is so you don't get ganked and die as often. 

I try to do that as much as I can. I have a lot of trouble when the enemy team has either a strong engage, think Gnar, Malphite, Maokai, Annie, Warwick, Amumu. Or when they have a lot of high damage divers. Think Fizz, Leblanc, Akali, Diana, Xin-Xiao. When they have more than one of either on the enemy team, I have a lot of problems with positioning. I often find myself being the only one who thinks about Malphite's ult or Fizz's E. I often don't know what to do other than wait for them to use their moves before going in. Problem is, you'll meet a lot of smart ones(usually on the enemy team of course) who hold on to their game changing abilities. And what happens usually, I'm forced to do little to nothing the entire time just waiting for Malphite to ult or for Fizz to use his E. My team dies many times during my wait and I'm left facing all of them by myself.

 Two divers is a real problem. I have to wait for not one, but two sets of cooldowns to be blown. I never know how to approach these fights especially when my team has no respect for their enemy's abilities. Often times I just say fuck it and go in mindlessly like the rest of my team and pray for some kind of fuck up on the enemy's team. Its a coin toss in other words. A lot of my deaths come from situations like this

 
> What I do when I am playing in bronze and trying to rank up is play a champ I am confident I can carry In. I then try my hardest to not only cs in lane, but win the lane by killing my opponent over & over. 

Can't tell you when last I was able to kill someone over and over again in a lane. I usually get 1 kill, maybe 2 and that's it. I have seen smurfs kill the enemy laner over and over again. Hell, I've had smurfs kill me over and over again in lane. I've been trying to figure out how they do this but I just can't figure it out. They just seem to be able to do this easily. 

Akali is the only champion I can get reliably fed on by abusing her powerful roams. Akali though is not really a reliable carry. Tanky teams fuck her up, she can't siege well, she can't splitpush all that good and her laning is among the weakest, ie, she gets bullied too easily in lane. She's only really good vs a team of squishy champs and she hasn't been bullied out of cs during the laning phase.

> then look for opportunities to gank lanes to 1. help my allies, but 2. more importantly try and get myself more kills.

 Another thing I've seen smurfs do really well. Half the time I do it, I get nothing. A smurf roams in a Bronze game, bet your ass he's getting a double or tripple kill. I need to learn what it is they see that I can't that tells them they will get something. 

I look for over extended lanes when I want to roam but with me what usually happens is that I get fucked over by the time it takes to reach to the lane I'm ganking ganking. For example, say I'm mid and I see the enemy bot pushing up against my team's bot lane tower. I start walking to bot. By the time I reach, the lane has reset, and they have backed off. I just roamed for nothing. I don't know what I can do to improve my odds. 

> I know its hard to see the light without experiencing it, but its there. Its embarrassing how much I have played this game and seeing how bad I am. I had probably 400-500 normal wins before even playing ranked in season 2. My elo in season 2 was probably the equivalent of bronze 4. Then when season 3 came around and the system changed I was put in bronze 4. I was pissed, but knew I had to work to rank up. Not sure why but I decided to play adc. I mained {{champion:110}} adc in season 3, which pretty much got me out of bronze. I laugh really hard about it now because I never play him anymore and I look back at my season 3 stats and see how terrible they are. Then in season 4 I got up to silver 2 and could not figure out why I could not get past it. Took literally over a year of grinding silver until roughly the end of season 5 before I realized silver 2 was my actual current elo. I finally realized I just needed to improve to start to rank up. It really did not take long to improve enough to reach gold after realizing that. Now I realize I will stick around gold 4-5 unless I continue to improve. 

Ya, I pretty much figured it would take a year to years to get out. I honestly thought it would have been easier given how people love to comment on how bad Bronze is. I'm discovering that it would take a lot more skill to get out than I originally thought.

> The good news is there is lots of things to improve on. Start with the basics and work your way up. Focus on winning your lane hard, but play safe if you fall behind. Focus on trying to catch enemies with ganks and try to snowball the game. Work on your team fight positioning. Warding and paying attention to your mini map is also important.

Ya, still working on those.

Something I've tried out to get better is playing practice custom games against better players 1:1 to improve my farming, poke and positioning. If you can find a better player willing to give you a little bit of time and you have an open mind, it's really very helpful. 

Alternatively, if you watch your own games after you finish playing them you can often see things you did wrong that you didn't notice while playing (for instance, last time I was watching myself play I was like "why do I keep running in the same circles? that's really predictable"). In the heat of the moment it's hard to see what could be improved, but I find there are a lot of things I can see if I watch the match again later. Try to focus on your actions only though, because that's all you can realistically control.

A reason why a lot of players are stuck in low elo is because match making fucks them up.
When you are on a winning spree, if your skill is higher than your rank it gets easier and easier to win because you are getting matched with people who has higher mmr/rank instead of the boosted animals you normally matched with. But if your winning spree ends, your immediately start getting matched with people who are in much lower mmr/rank than the ones you previously matched with, and it tilts people more than anything.

Also the amount of lp given when you win after a losing spree is so little. It takes much longer to get your mmr back to normal after a losing spree than a winning spree.(~5 wins to get rid of losing spree lp punishment, ~2 loses to get rid of all the winning spree lp reward)

Something I try to tell my friends who are low elo is: Skill does not exist in this game at all. It is simply knowledge. If you accept your mistakes and try to correct them (AKA better yourself) you will be climbing in no time. "Skill" has no effect on if you win or lose if you know what you can and can't do, when you can do it, and what the enemies can do, then you should win a lot more of your games.

Well how long it takes depends on a few things, mainly skill/win percentage. So my main account ended season 5 in gold 5 and after rank resent I was placed in silver 5. Season 6 started sometime in Mid January and I reached gold beginning of April (like April 2nd). Took 150-160 games. My win percentage was like roughly 54%. 

This account started season in 6 in bronze 2. Switched up roles and champs a little but took roughly 190 games to reach gold. win percentage stuck around 56%. 

Players who are smurfs (depending on where account starts or w/e) could reach gold really quickly. Someone who has a 70-80% win percentage will reach gold in a few games if not placed in it. 

So it really depends on how much your winning and what your accounts mmr is. For the average player reaching gold who is playing at that level you will probably have a 52-56 win%. Which like I showed can take a couple hundred games to reach. But new accounts or accounts that do not have a lot of games played in a season usually have a high starting mmr. So if players on those accounts go on win streaks they can sometimes skip divisions, and gain a large chunk of lp so ranking up can take only 50-60 games to reach gold. (if the account was not already placed into gold).
